title: My Kitchen Feels Cleaner and Safer After This One Change
description: Cleanliness isn’t always about scrubbing harder.
content:
Sometimes, the smallest adjustments make the biggest difference. For me, it was an almost laughably simple addition. Adding plastic liners to the bottom of every shelf made my drawers cleaner and changed how I feel about my entire space.

The bottoms of drawers and shelves are among the most overlooked and neglected spots in any home. They rarely catch the eye until that moment you reach for a jar of peanut butter, and your hand comes away sticky, or you notice an unexplained crust beneath the olive oil bottle.

In these hidden corners, grime accumulates silently over time. Dust settles, crumbs spill, sauces leak, and containers slowly ooze residue. The buildup is gradual and insidious because these areas don’t attract regular cleaning attention. When you finally do get around to tidying up, it often requires a deep, time-consuming scrub to restore the surfaces to a minimally hygienic state.

I vividly remember scraping at an old sticky patch beneath a spice rack. The frustration of having to empty an entire drawer just to clean one small spot felt frustrating and overwhelming. This happened more than once and felt like trying to tame a persistent, unseen mess.

This experience made me rethink: what if the shelves and drawers never got dirty in the first place?

Plastic shelf liners are exactly as they sound—protective barriers that sit on the bases of drawers, cupboards, and pantry shelves. They come in various materials, including flexible plastic or rubber, and in different styles, including clear, textured, patterned, grippy, or smooth.

Some liners have adhesive backs to stick firmly in place; others rely on their weight and surface texture to stay put without damaging the shelf underneath. The ones I selected were clear, non-adhesive liners from Costco with a lightly textured grip on one side. This texture prevents sliding, while the non-adhesive backing allows for easy removal and cleaning.

The crucial benefit is that these liners absorb all the abuse that would otherwise stain, warp, or rot the shelf surfaces themselves

The shift became apparent the very next time I spilled dry rice while restocking the pantry. Before using liners, spilled grains would scatter into every crevice and roll under containers. Cleaning this mess was a tedious, multi-step process. Unloading the entire shelf, sweeping by hand, then hunting down every last grain.

Now, I simply lift the liner, funnel the rice into the trash, give the liner a quick shake outdoors, and set it back down. The whole process takes less than a minute. Once you eliminate the underlying cause of the mess, you begin to realize how much time goes into “maintenance cleaning."

This ease applies to everything: spice dust, leaky honey, flour, cooking oil, and syrup rings. Rather than cleaning the shelves, I simply clean the liners. This subtle difference has saved me hours and alleviated the mental burden of worrying about sticky residue hiding beneath dishes. You don't need useful smart kitchen devices to improve the quality of your home; simple objects like this can have a noticeable impact.

Beyond convenience, shelf liners protect your stored items in unexpected ways. Glass bottles don’t clink as loudly. Plates remain more stable and don’t slide around. Even my mixing bowls have fewer scratches on their undersides. Liners cushion objects and reduce the risk of damage.

The effect is even more pronounced in drawers. My utensil organizer used to rattle with every movement, now it stays put. Knives no longer scrape against the wood base, and metal measuring cups are quieter when dropped in.

Plastic liners create a quiet, grounded feeling that makes the space feel more stable. It’s a small detail, but it makes the entire kitchen feel more composed and intentional.

Similar to other simple DIY kitchen projects, installing the liners is as straightforward and quick as you can imagine.

After emptying and wiping down each drawer and shelf, I simply made my measurements with a tape measure, drew my marks on the liner itself, and cut straight lines along the studded pattern. Each piece fit into its respective place like a glove.

If you’re not good with measurements, you can also opt to lay the liner over the surface, eyeball the dimensions, then trim it along the edges until it fits perfectly. No glue, no screws, no complex measurements—just unroll, cut, and place. The entire process is as simple as a few straight cuts.

Since adding liners, I open cabinets with confidence, reaching into back corners without hesitation. I no longer question whether the surface is sanitary or worry about what I might touch.

There’s a low-level tension we carry when unsure about a space’s cleanliness. It’s rarely conscious, but it lingers. Removing that anxiety has made cooking, cleaning, and snacking more enjoyable. A kitchen doesn’t need to be spotless to feel safe, it just needs to be manageable. Liners gave me that sense of control.

The psychological impact goes beyond simple convenience. There’s a calming effect in knowing the surfaces beneath your belongings are protected and easy to maintain. It fosters a sense of order in the space, which in turn influences how comfortable you feel there.

You could deep-clean shelves weekly, buy expensive custom inserts, or invest in over-engineered organizers. But liners offer the simplest, most cost-effective upgrade I’ve made.

Reusable paper liners tend to bunch and become soggy. Adhesive pads can tear your shelves when removed. Foam liners absorb liquids, leading to unpleasant odors and damage.

Plastic shelf liners are waterproof, durable, and easy to clean. They last a long time—even with daily use, I haven’t replaced a single piece since installation. They're also safe to store just about anywhere, unlike many other household items you shouldn't store under your sink.

Cost was another pleasant surprise. The two rolls I purchased as a bundle cost $26. An hour of my time yielded a lasting improvement that feels like something out of a newly remodeled kitchen.

Most kitchen upgrades fall into two categories: purely aesthetic (like backsplash) or painfully expensive (like new cabinetry). This simple upgrade is a practical, affordable change that makes you ask, “What else have I overlooked?”

Since then, I’ve extended liners to bathroom drawers and under-sink cabinets, resulting in a cleaner, safer, and easier to maintain home.

At first glance, spending $26 on plastic shelf liners might seem trivial, but the value quickly becomes apparent when you consider the time and effort saved.

Traditional deep-cleaning sessions can be lengthy and unpleasant, often requiring harsh chemicals that may degrade shelves over time. In contrast, liners simplify maintenance, turning what used to be a chore into a quick wipe-down. Beyond cleaning, they protect your cabinetry from stains, scratches, and moisture damage, potentially extending the life of your kitchen fixtures.

When you factor in the mental relief of a consistently tidy space, the modest upfront cost offers ongoing returns that far outweigh pricier renovations or cleaning products. Sometimes, a small, inexpensive change creates the biggest impact.

If you’re considering liners, here are a few recommendations:
• Measure first: Shelves typically range from 16 to 18 inches deep, but drawer sizes vary widely. Accurate measurements prevent waste.
• Avoid adhesive liners: Non-stick liners are easier to remove, replace, and clean.
• Choose textured or grippy liners: Smooth liners tend to slide around.
• Skip scented liners: They can develop unpleasant odors over time, and may clash with spices, cleaning products, or other scented objects you keep in your drawers.
• Buy extra: You’ll find more applications than you expect, such as toolboxes, closet shelves, under coffee machines—the possibilities are endless.

In just one afternoon, and for less than $30, I made my kitchen feel cleaner, safer, and more organized. It’s rare that such a small change offers such a meaningful payoff, but this one truly does. If you’ve been struggling with crumbs, stickiness, or the subtle dread of mystery stains, I highly recommend giving this a try. You’ll notice the difference immediately.
summary: Plastic shelf liners, or plastic protective barriers, are a simple addition to the bottom of every shelf that make your kitchen cleaner and safer. The author suggests that plastic liners cover the bottoms of drawers and shelves, which are often overlooked and neglected spots that accumulate in these areas without regular cleaning attention. The plastic linters from Costco have a non-adhesive grip on one side, which prevents sliding and allows for easy removal and cleaning. The liners absorb all the abuse that would otherwise stain, warp, or rot the shelf surfaces themselves. The ease of cleaning the liners eliminates the need for extensive thorough cleaning and maintenance cleaning, saving hours of time and time. The process is simple and straightforward, with no complex measurements or complex measurements required. The article also discusses the benefits of keeping items stored items more stable and more easily placed in drawers.
shortSummary: Plastic shelf liners enhance kitchen cleanliness and stability by covering the bottoms with durable, hard-to-reach material, without compromising design.

Craving a kitchen makeover but don’t have the budget for it? Does the sight of your kitchen make your heart sink whenever you pop in there to cook something? If you answered yes to either or both questions, you’ll be glad to know you don’t have to overhaul your kitchen to improve its appearance. Take a look at these DIY projects to inspire your next kitchen upgrade.
1. Kitchen LED Bar Lights
Lighting can make all the difference in a kitchen, turning it from a drab workspace to a cozy, inviting gathering place. And one fun and easy way to add some ambiance to your kitchen is with a DIY LED lighting project!
This particular Instructables guide shows you how to add LED lights to your kitchen bar, creating a warm and inviting glow, perfect for entertaining guests or relaxing with your family. The best part is that it's easy to do yourself, even if you're not a DIY expert.
All you need are some LED strips, a power supply, and a few basic tools, and you can transform your kitchen bar into a stylish and inviting space perfect for any occasion. So why not give it a try? Your kitchen will thank you for it! To further customize this project, you can make the RGB LED lights display DIY colors.
2. Knife Sharpening Angle Coach With Bluetooth & Arduino
A sharp knife is an essential kitchen tool. But sharpening knives can be a pain, especially if you are unsure of the angle to use. Fear not, though, because the nifty gadget created in this Arduino-based Instructables project will help you achieve the perfect angle every time by using data from an accelerometer and gyroscope to provide real-time feedback on your sharpening technique. Add in its Bluetooth connectivity and you can even monitor your progress on a smartphone or tablet.
3. Arduino Kitchen Timer
Do you find yourself burning your food because you forgot to set a timer? Or maybe you're tired of constantly checking the clock to see how much time is left on your recipe. Well, this Instructables guide has a DIY project to save the day! You can create your custom kitchen timer with just an Arduino board, some basic components, and a little coding.
This project allows you to set multiple timers, each with a unique countdown and alarm tone. Plus, you can customize the display with fun icons and even add voice commands to make it easier.
4. Gas Leakage Detector
Gas leaks are a serious safety hazard in any home, especially in the kitchen, which is why this DIY project on Instructables is a must-try if you want to ensure your kitchen is a safe place to cook and eat. The project uses sensors to detect the presence of gas and alerts you with an alarm if a leak is detected. Plus, with the bonus of monitoring the detector remotely using a smartphone app, you can have peace of mind even when you're away from home.
5. DIY Arduino Cocktail Machine
Tired of serving the same old drinks at your parties or gatherings? Why not mix things up with the fun and easy-to-build cocktail machine illustrated in this Hackster.io project? Once complete, you can make an endless array of cocktails at the push of a button thanks to the peristaltic pumps, solenoid valves, and motors used in its setup. Plus, you can customize the drinks with your recipes and even add an LCD to show off the ingredients and instructions.
6. Inexpensive iPad or Tablet Stand
Let’s face it! Holding your tablet or iPad while cooking is a game you can’t win. That’s where the inexpensive iPad or tablet stand shown in this Instructables guide comes in handy. It is simple to build, adjustable, and can accommodate various tablet sizes making it the perfect solution if you’ve been struggling to balance your tablet on a countertop or if you always try to prop it against a cookbook unsuccessfully.
If you prefer to check recipes on a smartphone, check out these DIY phone stands you can make in less than five minutes.
7. Trashcan Fill Level Indicator
Hate it when your trashcan overflows with garbage? Or do you forget to take out the trash until it’s too late? This Instructables guide has just the project you need to say goodbyes to the problem—a trashcan fill level indicator. It uses ultrasonic sensors connected to an Arduino to detect the fill level of your trashcan and generate real-time feedback through LEDs.
8. Make a Mini Fridge
Sometimes you just need a little extra fridge space in your kitchen, but buying a brand-new mini fridge can be expensive. Luckily, with the DIY project shown in this Instructables guide, you can create your own mini fridge for a fraction of the cost! It can keep your drinks and snacks cool, leaving more room in your main refrigerator.
9. Wok Clock
Don't toss out your old wok or pan just yet! With this Instructables tutorial, you can transform it into a stylish and functional clock that will add a modern touch to your kitchen. So, why settle for the boring clock that has been in your kitchen for ages when you can have a one-of-a-kind, eco-friendly piece? Are you looking for more inspiration to build a custom clock? Check out these stunning DIY clock ideas that are conversation starters.
10. Kitchen PC With Laptop Twist
Would you love to keep up with your favorite shows or stream music while you cook up a storm? The computer detailed in this Instructables guide is just what you need to breathe new life into your kitchen. The user turns (literally) an old laptop into a kitchen PC that can be mounted on the wall, providing easy access to recipes, entertainment, and more. And you, too, can pull it off easily.
11. Fire and Flood Alarm for the Kitchen
The fire and flood alarm is a must-try DIY project if you’re always concerned with kitchen safety. It uses an Arduino board and various sensors to detect smoke and water, alerting you of potential fires or floods before they get out of hand. Now you can rest easy knowing that your kitchen has an advanced alarm system that will alert you of potential hazards before they become a major problem. Check out this Instructables guide for details on how to easily complete this DIY project.
12. Magnetic Refrigerator Lights
Brighten up your kitchen and add some extra functionality with these DIY magnetic refrigerator lights. This easy-to-follow Instructables tutorial will guide you through the process of making magnetic lights that attach to your refrigerator or other metal surfaces. This project can be a good addition to the list of easy and profitable tech DIY crafts to make and sell, if you want to make an extra buck.
13. Simple Tea Bag Extractor
Sipping on a hot cup of tea can be a great way to relax and unwind, but dealing with those pesky tea bags can be a hassle. This is where the simple tea bag extractor comes in! This Instructables guide will teach you how to make a handy tool that easily extracts your tea bag from your cup without any mess or fuss. Say goodbye to burning your fingers or fishing out tea bags with spoons!
Key Takeaways and Final Thoughts
Transform your kitchen without breaking the bank with these 13 DIY kitchen projects! From adding LED lighting to your kitchen bar and creating a gas leakage detector to making a custom kitchen timer, these easy-to-follow projects are perfect for any level of DIY expertise. Give your kitchen the upgrade it deserves, and try out these fun projects today!

Many people treat the space underneath their kitchen sink like a larger junk drawer. But you might be surprised to know that many items in your home shouldn't be kept under the sink.
5 Cleaning Rags, Sponges, and Paper Products
For the sake of accessibility and convenience, many people throw rags for cleaning the kitchen, grocery bags, and similar goods under the sink. Sponges are another common item of this type, since they're used all the time for washing dishes. While these three items sound like they'd be ideally suited for storage under the sink, doing so is a mistake.
Although rare, you could have plumbing problems in your kitchen, where even a small leak could cause significant damage. That water getting where it's not intended could destroy many items placed underneath, including paper products and those mentioned above. Additionally, the cabinets below a sink are prone to being a breeding ground for mold and mildew, which you don’t want to spread to other areas of your home.
Instead of storing cleaning rags, sponges, and paper products under the sink, place them in an adjacent drawer or a utility closet. They’ll still be in the kitchen, but better protected.
4 Food and Perishable Goods
For many of the same reasons, food and perishable goods have no business being stored underneath the kitchen sink. The potential for mold and bacteria to accumulate under the sink is obviously bad news for any food you’re planning to eat.
There’s also the possibility of pest infestation. It's easier to miss the signs of rodents and other pests getting into your food when it's hidden under the sink, compared to in plain sight.
This limited accessibility and visibility are other reasons to put your fresh fruit elsewhere. Forgetting where food is only to find it spoiled or rotten later is a mess, and not enjoyable.
Keep anything perishable in the fridge, where it's still easily accessible (though that might require some rearranging for best results). For items that don’t require a cooler temperature, such as canned goods, flour, cereal, and pasta, a kitchen pantry is best. At a minimum, place these items in a dedicated kitchen cabinet that’s easily accessible.
While this comes as no surprise, it won't help you keep indoor plants alive to put them under the sink, either. They need their light!
3 Household Chemicals and Pesticides
While the various sprays in your home have plenty of uses, all those chemicals mean they can also be dangerous. By placing them below the sink, these items become easily accessible to children and pets. And because the area under the kitchen sink typically lacks adequate ventilation, those chemicals can leak and accumulate dangerous fumes.
Many household chemicals are also highly flammable. So, storing them in an enclosed space near a potential heat source (like hot water pipes) is a significant fire risk.
In my home, I store all household chemicals in a locked, but ventilated, cabinet in my basement. It’s out of the reach of young children and nowhere near food. And inside the cabinet, the chemicals are stored on a non-absorbent surface.
2 Extra Trash Bags
The under-sink area is also a poor choice for storing extra trash bags or plastic bags from stores. Biodegradable or compostable bags also have no place in the kitchen under the sink. While you don't want them to get wet or grow mold, there’s another reason not to store bags here: child and pet safety. A young child or your dog could face a suffocation risk by playing with a bag.
Ideally, you should store bags in a utility closet or a cabinet located above the sink, out of the reach of children. If you have no place to store your many trash bags, consider replacing them with a smaller number of reusable ones and placing them in the same area as you would the others.
1 Small Appliances and Electronics
About a year ago, I found myself swept up in the personal blender craze. My short-term obsession became so bad that I bought two, as the first one didn’t perform that well. Alas, I soon found both small appliances sitting idle under my kitchen sink.
When the time came to use one, I realized one of its batteries had started to leak. While I don’t know what happened for sure, I imagine a water leak a few months before probably caused it.
This illustrates why you shouldn’t store small appliances, handy smart kitchen devices, or electronics under your sink. Besides the potential for water damage, pest infestation, and chemical exposure, the appliance itself can cause problems, especially if it’s battery-operated.
Instead of storing these small appliances under the sink, place them on your kitchen tabletop where they are easier to see and access. If that’s not possible, put them in a basement or dedicated pantry.
Living under the kitchen isn't the right condition for all home items. Some could get damaged by being stored in an area that’s closed and prone to water leaks. Others shouldn’t be there because you might forget about them, while still others are dangerous items that shouldn’t be stored in confined areas.

Quick Links
Summary
- You can use smart kitchen devices for several purposes, such as brewing coffee and cooking food.
- Automating your daily tasks will save significant time and may ease the clean-up process.
- Use smart kitchen devices if you already have the non-smart versions or know you'll use them.
Some smart kitchen appliances are less useful than others, but that doesn’t mean you should ditch them altogether. Keep reading to discover six of the best you should consider getting for your own home, with real-life use cases.
1 Air Fryer
I like cooking my food for the health benefits of knowing exactly what’s going into my body and I also find it quite theraputic. However, that does not mean I want to actively be in the kitchen all the time. And while I eat the same base ingredients most of the time, I sometimes struggle for inspiration and ideas. In both instances, a smart air fryer can play a key role.
In my opinion, getting recipes with a smart air fryer is one of its biggest advantages. While I’ve been cooking my own food for over a decade, I still like trying new things. And for someone new to healthy eating, I can imagine—based on my experiences as a beginner—that not having to search online makes a big difference.
Another benefit of using smart air fryers is that you can pre-set them if you eat your meals at a certain time. When I meal prep, for example, I used to dislike eating cold food (but I disliked the labor of reheating even more). In my opinion, a smart air fryer is a viable alternative in these instances.
2 Coffee Maker
I’m very sensitive to caffeine and try to limit my consumption to days when I don’t exercise in the morning. However, I enjoy having coffee as a treat—meaning that a good coffee maker would add value to my life. Smart coffee machines can be a viable alternative to an ordinary coffee maker, and they’re often not as expensive as you might think.
Smart coffee makers give you more options for creating the exact drink you want, saving you the time required to visit a café. You can also set your coffee to brew while you’re getting ready for the day rather than manually going to the kitchen and adjusting your settings. Just make sure you put the mug where it should be the night before!
Another advantage of a smart coffee maker is that you can turn it off when you leave the house without needing to press any buttons on the machine. If you aren’t sure where to start, consider checking out these great smart coffee machines.
3 Pressure Cooker
I’ve always loved pressure cookers, especially if I want to prepare my meals beforehand. Recipes like meatballs, pulled chicken or pork, and various soups taste so much better when left to cook on a lower heat for hours. Smart pressure cookers can make everything much easier and they have many of the same benefits as a smart air fryer.
One of my biggest annoyances with an ordinary pressure cooker was that I sometimes found it harder to release the pressure after my meal was ready. This problem is eliminated with a smart pressure cooker because your device will do it automatically.
While you can find recipes online, you’ll sometimes need to scale things up or down depending on the specific number of ingredients that you’re using. I do not like math in any way, shape, or form; one particularly great thing about smart pressure cookers is that you can use presets to automatically scale your cooking requirements.
Another limitation I found with ordinary pressure cookers was that you had to regularly walk into the kitchen and see how your food was doing. This wasn’t a problem when I worked from home, but it naturally became an issue when I realized how much I disliked working from home and rented a coworking space. With a smart pressure cooker, you can check how your meal is doing via an app instead.
4 Kettle With Adjustable Temperature
Since I was born in the UK, I have a natural inclination towards a good cup of tea when it’s cold outside. Don’t get me wrong—an ordinary kettle usually works well without a problem. However, the majority of kettles don’t let you control the temperature. So, if you’re not happy with the result, you normally have to wait for your drink to cool down.
This isn’t a problem for me (luckily, I’m also part Italian, and we have a special skill for drinking beverages while they’re still piping hot). But wouldn’t it be great if you could literally just choose the temperature and avoid all problems? Well, a smart kettle can allow you to do precisely that.
Many smart kettles let you choose the preferred temperature for your water, and you can often pick how long you want the liquid to be warm. So, if you’re fed up with manually turning on your kettle (or the temperature not being right for you), you should strongly consider getting one.
I’d recommend getting a smart kettle instead of a coffee maker if you like pressing your coffee instead of having a machine making it for you.
5 Smart Water Purifier
One thing I’ve learned when taking my health more seriously is that “safe” drinking water doesn’t always mean “optimal”. While purifiers won’t necessarily get rid of everything, I have found getting one to be quite beneficial; the same goes for my LARQ water bottle (which self-cleans every few hours, and yes, I really did spend $100+ on a water bottle).
With a smart water purification system, you can always have clean water available for hot and cold drinks.
If you don’t want to buy a kettle or coffee maker but still enjoy warm beverages, some smart water purifiers will also let you adjust the temperature. However, I would keep in mind that you may need to be more physically present than you would with a smart coffee maker. So, if you want your coffee ready after your morning shower or run, it’s a good idea to get a smart coffee maker instead.
6 Smart Blender
I never realized how much I needed a blender until I moved into a new house and didn’t have one available. Smoothies are one of my favorite post-workout “snacks”, and they’re also a great weekend treat. While they’re easy to manually clean (and also make the smoothies themselves), it is nice if you can free up some of that work.
Since I typically like to take a shower when back from the gym and prepare for my day, I would prefer to focus more on my time doing that. With a smart blender, you can use an app to blend your ingredients and have everything ready when needed. You won’t save much time considering that you have to put the ingredients in there yourself, but it’s still a handy tool.
You’ll find handy smart kitchen devices for all kinds of activities, from cooking food to purifying your water. I recommend getting one only if you’re already using a manual version or know that you’ll use the smart edition more frequently. Nonetheless, you’ll find several advantages if you do.

argos_summary: The article explains how adding non‑adhesive plastic shelf liners to drawers and cabinets can dramatically reduce mess, simplify cleaning, protect surfaces, and improve kitchen organization for a modest $26 investment. It details the easy installation process, the practical benefits such as preventing stains and keeping items stable, and the psychological relief of a consistently tidy space. The piece also includes a curated list of 13 DIY kitchen projects—from LED lighting and gas leak detectors to custom timers and mini fridges—that offer cost‑effective upgrades and safety enhancements. Together, the article highlights simple, affordable solutions that transform everyday kitchen maintenance and inspire further creative improvements.
